question: Question_Section_201_05_(c)
statement:
Consider the following graph, interpreted as a resistor network with all
resistances \emph{R = 1}.

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{MATH307April2013Section201Q5a.png}
\end{description}

\textbf{(c)} Suppose that by attaching a battery, the voltage at vertex
1 is held at \emph{b\textsubscript{1}} and the voltage at vertex 2 is
held at \emph{b\textsubscript{2}}. Write down vectors \textbf{\emph{v}}
and \emph{\textbf{J}} so that the equation \emph{L\textbf{v}} =
\textbf{\emph{J}} describes this situation. Explain what each entry of
\textbf{\emph{v}} and \textbf{\emph{J}} represents, and how you can use
the entries to compute the effective resistance between vertices 1 and
2.
sols:
\[\vec{v} = \begin{bmatrix}
b_1\\b_2\\v_3\\v_4\\v_5\\v_6
\end{bmatrix}\]

Here every entry is the voltage at the corresponding node.
\emph{b\textsubscript{1}} and \emph{b\textsubscript{2}} are the voltages
held by the battery connected at nodes 1 and 2.

\[\vec{J} = \begin{bmatrix}
c\\-c\\0\\0\\0\\0
\end{bmatrix}\]

Here every entry is the current flowing into/out of the corresponding
node. \emph{c} is the current coming out of node 1 from the battery,
\emph{-c} is the current coming out of node 2 from the battery.

To find \emph{R\textsubscript{eff}} remember Ohm's law: \emph{V=IR}.
Hence

\[R_{\mathrm{eff}} = \frac{b_2-b_1}{c}\]

Notice that \emph{c} is determined by the resistance of the rest of the
circuit. If \emph{c} is unknown, the effective resistance can be
computed using Schur$^{\prime}$s Complement. Remember:

\[S = \frac{1}{R_{\mathrm{eff}}}\begin{bmatrix} 1 & -1\\ -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\]
